title: MIT License
text: library provided MIT License. gb-io Rust crate package written David Leslie licensed terms MIT License. project way affiliated, sponsored, otherwise endorsed original gb-io authors.

title: Introduction to rgbio
text: rgbio provides high-performance interface gb-io Rust crate reading writing GenBank files. designed fast memory-efficient providing R-friendly data structures. Important note: package written primarily LLMs (“AI”) direction, uses robust Rust gb-io crate tested NCBI example GenBank files. mostly project play around agents “AI-tools”, provide real value.

title: Introduction to rgbio
text: can install rgbio GitHub, provided Rust toolchain installed.

title: Introduction to rgbio
text: write GenBank file, need three components: 1. Sequence: DNA RNA string. 2. Features: data.frame describing annotations. 3. Metadata: list file-level attributes (definition, accession, etc.). Let’s create minimal example sequence. Now, write temporary file:
code: # 1. The sequence seq_dna <- "ATGCGTACGTTAGC"  # 2. Metadata metadata <- list(   definition = "Synthetic Example Sequence",   accession = "EX0001",   version = "1",   molecule_type = "DNA",   topology = "linear",   division = "SYN",   date = "01-JAN-2023" )  # 3. Features # Note: 'qualifiers' must be a list column where each element is a named character vector. features_df <- data.frame(   key = c("source", "gene", "CDS"),   location = c("1..14", "1..14", "1..14"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  features_df$qualifiers <- list(   c(organism = "Synthetic Organism", mol_type = "genomic DNA"),   c(gene = "exampleGene"),   c(gene = "exampleGene", product = "hypothetical protein", translation = "MRTS") )  # Preview features print(features_df) #>      key location                              qualifiers #> 1 source    1..14         Synthetic Organism, genomic DNA #> 2   gene    1..14                             exampleGene #> 3    CDS    1..14 exampleGene, hypothetical protein, MRTS tmp_file <- tempfile(fileext = ".gb") write_genbank(tmp_file, seq_dna, features_df, metadata) #> [1] TRUE

title: Introduction to rgbio
text: Reading straightforward. read_genbank parses file returns list records.
code: records <- read_genbank(tmp_file)  # We wrote only one record length(records) #> [1] 1  record <- records[[1]]

title: Introduction to rgbio
text: returned record three components matching wrote. Metadata: Sequence: Features: features returned tidy data.frame.
code: str(record$metadata) #> List of 12 #>  $ name         : chr "EX0001" #>  $ definition   : chr "Synthetic Example Sequence" #>  $ accession    : chr "EX0001" #>  $ version      : chr "1" #>  $ keywords     : chr(0)  #>  $ source       : chr "" #>  $ organism     : chr NA #>  $ molecule_type: chr "DNA" #>  $ topology     : chr "linear" #>  $ division     : chr "SYN" #>  $ date         : chr "01-JAN-2023" #>  $ references   : list() record$sequence #> [1] "ATGCGTACGTTAGC" print(record$features) #>      key location   qualifiers #> 1 source    1..14 Syntheti.... #> 2   gene    1..14  exampleGene #> 3    CDS    1..14 exampleG....

title: Introduction to rgbio
text: following metadata fields supported write_genbank() returned read_genbank(): name (Locus name) definition accession version keywords (character vector) source organism molecule_type (e.g., “DNA”) division topology (“linear” “circular”) date (format: DD-MON-YYYY) references (list references; reference may include description, authors, consortium, title, journal, pubmed, remark)

title: Introduction to rgbio
text: rgbio supports complex GenBank locations, including joins, complements, fuzziness, parsing standard location strings. advanced manipulations location strings arithmetic, may need parse location column rely external Bioconductor packages. rgbio focuses faithful IO.

title: Introduction to rgbio
text: rgbio leverages Rust’s zero-copy parsing possible efficient string handling outperform pure R implementations, especially large multi-record GenBank files.

title: Introduction to rgbio
text: library provided MIT License. gb-io Rust crate package written David Leslie licensed terms MIT License. project way affiliated, sponsored, otherwise endorsed original gb-io authors.

text: Stöckl R (2026). rgbio: High-Performance GenBank /O using 'gb-io'. R package version 0.0.0.9000.
code: @Manual{,   title = {rgbio: High-Performance GenBank I/O using 'gb-io'},   author = {Richard Stöckl},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000}, }

title: rgbio
text: rgbio provides high-performance interface Rust gb-io crate reading writing GenBank files. designed fast memory-efficient providing R-friendly data structures. Important note: package written primarily LLMs (“AI”) direction, uses robust Rust gb-io crate tested NCBI example GenBank files. mostly project play around agents “AI-tools”, provide real value.

title: rgbio
text: can install rgbio GitHub. Rust toolchain (cargo rustc) must available.

title: rgbio
code: library(rgbio)  # Minimal example seq_dna <- "ATGCGTACGTTAGC" metadata <- list(   definition = "Synthetic Example Sequence",   accession = "EX0001",   version = "1",   molecule_type = "DNA",   topology = "linear",   division = "SYN",   date = "01-JAN-2023" )  features_df <- data.frame(   key = c("source", "gene", "CDS"),   location = c("1..14", "1..14", "1..14"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  features_df$qualifiers <- list(   c(organism = "Synthetic Organism", mol_type = "genomic DNA"),   c(gene = "exampleGene"),   c(gene = "exampleGene", product = "hypothetical protein", translation = "MRTS") )  tmp_file <- tempfile(fileext = ".gb") write_genbank(tmp_file, seq_dna, features_df, metadata)  records <- read_genbank(tmp_file) str(records[[1]])

title: rgbio
text: main vignette available via:

title: Read a GenBank file — read_genbank
text: Parses GenBank file returns list sequences, features, metadata.

title: Read a GenBank file — read_genbank
text: file Path GenBank file.

title: Read a GenBank file — read_genbank
text: list records, record contains: metadata list metadata supported fields: name (Locus name) definition accession version keywords (character vector) source organism molecule_type (e.g., "DNA") division topology ("linear" "circular") date (format: DD-MON-YYYY) references (list references; reference may include description, authors, consortium, title, journal, pubmed, remark) features data frame features (key, location, qualifiers) sequence sequence string

title: Write a GenBank file — write_genbank
text: Writes sequences features GenBank format file.

title: Write a GenBank file — write_genbank
text: file Path output file. sequence Character string containing sequence (DNA/RNA). features Data frame features. Must contain columns: key: Feature type (e.g., "CDS", "gene") location: Location string (e.g., "1..100") qualifiers: List column named character vectors metadata Named list metadata (optional). Supported fields: name (Locus Name) definition accession version keywords (character vector) source organism molecule_type (e.g., "DNA") division topology ("linear" "circular") date (format: DD-MON-YYYY) references (list references; reference may include description, authors, consortium, title, journal, pubmed, remark)

title: Write a GenBank file — write_genbank
text: Logical TRUE success.

title: Write a GenBank file — write_genbank
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{   meta <- list(definition = "Example Sequence", accession = "AB0001")   feats <- data.frame(     key = "source",      location = "1..100",      qualifiers = I(list(c(organism = "Homo sapiens")))   )   write_genbank("out.gb", "ATGC...", feats, meta) } # }

title: rgbio 0.0.0.9000
text: Initial development version read/write support GenBank files. R bindings Rust gb-io crate via extendr. Test coverage includes NCBI example GenBank files.
